revisions.rev:
[[Image:9TH Manny Acta.jpg|thumb|right|225px|[[Manny Acta]] is the current Indians manager.]] The [[Cleveland Indians]] are a [[Professional sports league organization#The system developed in baseball|professional baseball franchise]] based in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]] that formed in [[1901 Major League Baseball season|1901]]. They are members of the [[American League Central|Central]] division of [[Major League Baseball]]'s [[American League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CLE/|title=Cleveland Indians History & Encyclopedia|publisher=Sports Reference LLC|accessdate=2010-07-17 }}</ref>
The Indians have had 44 [[manager (baseball)|managers]] in their history. [[Jimmy McAleer]] became the first manager of the then Cleveland Blues in 1901, serving for one season. In 1901, McAleer was replaced with [[Bill Armour]]. The Indians made their first playoff appearance under [[Tris Speaker]] in [[1920 Major League Baseball season|1920]]. Out of the six managers that have led the Indians into the postseason, only Speaker and [[Lou Boudreau]] have led the Indians to [[World Series]] championships, doing so in [[1920 World Series|1920]] and [[1948 World Series|1948]], respectively. [[Al Lopez]] lost the [[1954 World Series]] in four games to the [[San Francisco Giants|New York Giants]]. [[Mike Hargrove]] lost the [[1995 World Series]] and [[1997 World Series]] with the Indians. The highest [[winning percentage]] of any manager who managed at least one season was Lopez, with a percentage of .617. The lowest percentage was [[Johnny Lipon]]'s .305 in 1971 , although he managed for only 59 games. The lowest percentage of a manager with at least one season with the Indians was McAleer's .397 in 1901.
Armour became the first manager who held the title of manager for the Indians for more than one season. Hargrove has managed more games than any other Indians manager. [[Charlie Manuel]], [[Eric Wedge]], Speaker, Boudreau, Lopez, and Hargrove are the only managers to have led the Indians into the playoffs. Speaker, Boudreau, Lopez, [[Walter Johnson]], [[Joe Gordon]], [[Nap Lajoie]] and [[Frank Robinson]] are the seven members of the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|Baseball Hall of Fame]] who are also former managers of this club. Of those seven, Lopez is the only one inducted as a manager.<ref name=general>{{cite web|title=Cleveland Indians Managers|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CLE/managers.shtml|accessdate=2010-07-25 |publisher=Sports Reference LLC}}</ref><ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/teams/CLE/hof.shtml|title=Cleveland Indians Hall of Fame Register|accessdate=2010-07-18 |publisher=Sports Reference LLC}}</ref><ref>{{citeweb|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20081208&content_id=3705907&vkey=news_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb|title=Veterans elect '40s star Gordon to Hall|accessdate=2010-07-19 |publisher=mlb.com}}</ref>
The highest win–loss total for a Indians manager is held by Boudreau, with 728 wins and 649 losses.<ref name=general/> Wedge became the first Indians manager to win the [[Manager of the Year]] award, in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/manage.shtml|title=Manager of the Year Award Winners|publisher=Sports Reference LLC|accessdate=2010-07-30 }}</ref> The current manager of the Indians is [[Manny Acta]], who replaced Wedge after the [[2009 Major League Baseball season|2009 season]].
==Table key== {| class="wikitable" |- |<center>'''WPct'''</center>||Winning percentage: number of wins divided by number of games managed |- |<center>'''PA'''</center>||Playoff appearances: number of years this manager has led the franchise to the [[Major League Baseball postseason|playoffs]] |- |<center>'''PW'''</center>||Playoff wins: number of wins this manager has accrued in the playoffs |- |<center>'''PL'''</center>||Playoff losses: number of losses this manager has accrued in the playoffs |- |<center>'''WS'''</center>||World Series: number of [[World Series]] victories achieved by this manager |- |bgcolor="#ffffbb"|<center>â ''or'' â¡</center>||Elected to the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame]] (â¡ denotes induction as manager)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baseball-reference.com/awards/hof.shtml|title=Baseball Hall of Fame Inductees|publisher=Sports Reference LLC|accessdate=2008-12-29}}</ref> |}
==Managers== [[Image:Jmcaleer.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Jimmy McAleer became the first manager of the then Cleveland Blues in 1901.]] [[Image:Nap Lajoie.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Nap Lajoie]] served as [[player-manager]] from 1905 to 1909.]] [[Image:Tris_Speaker.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Tris Speaker led the Indians to a [[1920 World Series|World Championship in 1920.]]]] [[Image:MikeHargrove.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Mike Hargrove (seen here as the manager of the [[Seattle Mariners]]), led the Indians to five playoff appearances.]]
